School of Food Biotechnology and Chemical Engineering Hankyong National University 327 Jungang-ro Anseong 17579 Republic of Korea The scarce, expensive Pt is the preferred catalyst for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in metal–air batteries or fuel cells. In this study, a composite catalyst consisting of cobalt sulfide and polyaniline (PANI) was utilized for optimal ORR kinetics. Cobalt sulfide catalysts were prepared at different temperatures, the optimal cobalt sulfide catalyst was coated with PANI, and the coated catalyst was annealed to form a core–shell cobalt sulfide@NC composite catalyst. Structural characterization was performed via X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) were conducted to characterize the catalyst morphology. CoS-160 exhibited a flower-like structure; CoS-180, containing Co9S8, exhibited both flower-like and sheet structures; and CoS-200 exhibited a sheet structure. With an increase in temperature, XRD and Raman spectroscopy verified the formation of Co9S8, serving as ORR active sites, in CoS-180 and CoS-200. HR-TEM indicated that the Co9S8-x@NC catalysts had a core–shell structure. Among them, Co9S8–180@NC had the highest graphitization degree, and total nitrogen, pyridinic N, graphitic N contents, resulting in the highest onset potential, limiting current density and the lowest Tafel slope for ORR in alkaline media among the catalysts. In an accelerated stress test, a performance degradation of less than 1 % was observed, and a chronoamperometry test demonstrated a current retention rate of 95.49 %. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cobalt sulfide Polyaniline Nonprecious metal catalysts Core–shell structure Oxygen reduction reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to their high efficiency and low emissions, anion-exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs) are a promising clean energy conversion system capable of directly converting hydrogen energy into electrical energy [1]. A major issue in the operation of fuel cells is the slow oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode [2,3]. Although Pt-based electrocatalysts can improve the ORR rate, they have several drawbacks, such as low stability, high cost, and limited availability [1,2]. Thus, researchers are extensively studying nonprecious metal catalysts (NPMCs) as alternatives [4–7]. Various electrocatalysts have been developed for ORR, such as metal-free carbon catalysts [8,9], metal-containing carbon catalysts [10,11], and transition metal compounds [7,12]. Transition metals and transition metal compounds based on Fe, Co, and Mn are attracting significant interest as ORR catalysts due to their high efficiency, durability, abundance, and low cost [13–16]. Fe-based catalysts exhibit excellent ORR activity, but the Fenton reaction can oxidize Fe, thus degrading active sites [17,18]. Co-based catalysts have lower ORR activity than Fe-based catalysts but maintain higher stability, as they are not affected by the Fenton reaction [14]. Therefore, they are promising alternative ORR catalysts for fuel cells [19–22]. Among Co-based catalysts, cobalt sulfides have been extensively studied and can form compounds with various stoichiometric states, such as CoS, CoS2, Co3S4, and Co9S8 [13,23]. In various compositions of cobalt sulfides, Co9S8 is a strong candidate ORR electrocatalyst [24–26]. Co9S8 can be synthesized through various routes, including direct formation via a hydrothermal synthesis pathway or composition modification through additional pyrolysis processes of cobalt sulfides [24,25]. According to Zhu [25], CoS decomposes through pyrolysis at high temperatures, forming Co9S8. However, Co9S8 nanoparticles alone cannot exhibit adequate catalytic activity due to their agglomeration, low specific surface area, and low conductivity [25,27]. Therefore, researchers aim to enhance their catalytic activity by integrating Co9S8 nanoparticles into porous carbon, graphene, and nitrogen-doped carbon [23,25,28]. Nitrogen-doped carbon, where nitrogen is integrated into various carbon materials (such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and carbon black), is typically used as a material for NPMCs [29–31]. This study involves the use of polyaniline (PANI), which is a conductive polymer containing both nitrogen and carbon [32]. PANI is advantageous for creating active sites in nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts, as it preserves its nanostructure after pyrolysis. Additionally, various synthesis methods can be used to produce PANI in various forms and properties, depending on the synthesis conditions [33–37]. Nitrogen-doped carbon materials with nitrogen dopants in the forms of pyridinic N and graphitic N can enhance the electrocatalytic performance of catalysts by facilitating electron transfer during ORR [32–34]. Incorporating two or three heteroatoms into carbon materials can further enhance the ORR electrocatalytic activity of a catalyst [4,38,39]. The main reason is that the synergy between dopants generates greater asymmetric spin and a higher charge density compared with single-heteroatom doping [40]. Co-doping with sulfur can further strengthen the ORR activity by increasing the positive charge density and electron spin density of adjacent carbon atoms, thereby promoting the preferential adsorption of oxygen molecules [25]. The preferred combination for co-doping is nitrogen and another heteroatom [4]. During co-doping with nitrogen and sulfur, nitrogen, which has a higher electronegativity than carbon, induces a positive charge density in the adjacent carbon atoms, facilitating oxygen adsorption and charge transfer, thereby acting as an active site and enhancing the ORR activity [41,42]. Sulfur has a similar electronegativity to carbon, so it is less effective as an active site. However, it can create defects in the carbon framework, which may serve as sites for oxygen adsorption [43,44]. The activity and durability of NPMCs are much lower than those of Pt catalysts, but Co-based NPMCs are good alternatives for the cathode catalysts in AEMFCs [45–48]. This study was designed to obtain Co9S8 nanoparticles encapsulated in carbon co-doped with nitrogen and sulfur using a simple approach without templates. The synthesis process was divided into three steps as follows. CoS catalysts were synthesized under various temperature conditions and encapsulated in PANI. Next, the CoS@PANI catalysts were annealed at high temperatures to form activated Co9S8@NC composite catalysts. Various physical and electrochemical analyses were performed on the catalysts to check for any improvement in their electrochemical activity through changes in their morphologies, chemical structures, and electronic structures. The catalyst structure, CoS species, and ORR electrocatalytic activity could be controlled by adjusting the synthesis temperature. Due to its high graphitization degree, long Co–S bond length, and high contents of total N, pyridinic N and graphitic N, Co9S8–180@NC exhibited the best catalytic performance in terms of the onset potential (0.80 V). Furthermore, it showed high durability in 10,000 potential cycles and methanol tolerance tests. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of CoS-x (x = 160 °C, 180 °C, 200 °C) First, 0.5 g of cobalt (Ⅱ) acetate tetrahydrate and 1.875 g of thiourea were added to 15 mL of deionized (DI) water (18.2 MΩ cm), and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. The stirred mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon liner, which was then placed in a stainless-steel autoclave and reacted at 160 °C, 180 °C, or 200 °C for 24 h. During this process, the ramping rate was set to 5 °C·min−1. After the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Subsequently, the mixture was washed with ethanol and DI water. Finally, it was dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C overnight. The resulting catalysts were labeled CoS-x, where x represented the synthesis temperature. 2.2 Preparation of Co9S8-x@NC Here, 0.5 g of CoS-x was homogeneously ultrasonicated in 100 mL of a 0.5 M hydrochloric acid solution. The prepared solution was poured into a jacketed beaker at 3 °C. Simultaneously, 100 μL of aniline was mixed with the solution in the jacketed beaker. Then, 0.3063 g of ammonium persulfate (APS) was dissolved in cold DI water and poured into the jacketed beaker slowly. This mixture was stirred for 3 h to facilitate polymerization. The mixture was removed via filtration, and the resultant solid was washed with DI water. It was then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C overnight. The obtained catalysts were labeled CoS-x@PANI. Next, CoS-x@PANI was annealed at 800 °C for 1 h in a nitrogen atmosphere. The synthesized catalysts were named Co9S8-x@NC. 2.3 Physicochemical characterization The dispersion and ratio of the constituent atoms on the catalyst surface were analyzed using a field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM; SUPRA40VP, Carl Zeiss, Germany). The crystal structure of the synthesized cobalt sulfides were compared using X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Smartlab, Rigaku, Japan). Raman spectra were collected using a Renishaw inVia™ confocal Raman microscope (United Kingdom). The compound composition and electronic states of the surface elements were identified through a comparative analysis of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Nexsa, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Korea). The catalyst structure was observed through transmission electron microscopy (TEM; Titan 80–300, FEI, United States), and the corresponding lattice planes, identified via XRD, were compared and analyzed. 2.4 Electrochemical characterization Electrochemical measurements were conducted using a three-electrode system with a bipotentiostat (DY2300, Digi-lvy, United States) and a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE, WaveVortex 10, Pine Research, United States). The counter, reference, and working electrodes were Pt mesh, mercury/mercury oxide, and glassy carbon (GC; d = 5.6 mm), respectively. The catalyst ink was prepared as follows. 8 mg of the synthesized catalyst was sequentially mixed with 776 μL of 2-propanol (IPA; 99.8 %, SAMCUN, Korea) and 24 μL of Nafion (rD-521 dispersion, 5 % w/w in water and 1-propanol, Alfa Aesar, United States) and then ultrasonically dispersed for 30 min using an ultrasonic processor (Q55 Sonicator, Qsonica, United States). Then, 15 μL of the dispersed catalyst ink was applied to the GC to achieve a catalyst loading of 0.6 mg·cm−2, followed by 5 μL of a binder (1:19 = Nafion:IPA). In all tests, the electrolyte was 0.1 M KOH (SAMCUN, Korea), and the measured potential values were calibrated with respect to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The potential with respect to RHE (ERHE) was calculated as E R H E = E H g / H g O + 0.098 + 0.059 × p H . During linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements, a potential range of 0.05–1.2 V (vs. RHE) was scanned at a rate of 5 mV·s −1, with the ring electrode potential set to 1.2 V (vs. RHE). In the non-Faradaic region, cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis was performed at scan rates of 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 mV·s −1 to calculate the electric double-layer capacitance (EDLC). In the equations below, ja and jc represent the maximum and minimum current values in the anodic and cathodic scans, respectively; Vb is the scan rate; Cdl represents the EDLC. Δ j = j a − j c C d l = d ( Δ j ) 2 d V b The electrochemical resistance of the catalyst was analyzed and compared by performing electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at 0.6 V in an frequency range of 10,000 Hz to 1 Hz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterization of catalysts The morphology of the synthesized catalysts was observed using SEM (Fig. 1 ). The SEM images of the CoS-x catalysts (Fig. 1 (a-c)) show that CoS-160 exhibits a distinct nanoflake structure. As the synthesis temperature increases to 180 °C and 200 °C, the nanoflake structures gradually cluster into a more aggregated particle form. In the case of CoS-160, the overall catalyst particles exhibit a flower-like structure; as the hydrothermal synthesis temperature increases, some of the flower structures disappear in CoS-180 and sheet structures emerge (Fig. S1(a) and S1(b)). CoS-200 has a fully developed sheet structure (Fig. S1(c)). As for CoS-x@PANI (Fig. 1 (d-f)), PANI coats CoS-x in an aggregated form, and the catalyst structure remains intact after pyrolysis (Fig. 1(g-i)). The appearance of PANI in this aggregated form rather than as nanofibers is attributed to the low polymerization temperature, the ratio of the monomer to the oxidant (APS), and the slow polymerization rate due to the gradual addition of the oxidant [33,34,48]. Fig. 2 and Table 1 show the SEM–energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images and results, which were used to observe the atomic composition and distribution on the catalyst surface. The results for CoS-180 show that the Co and S elements are evenly distributed across the catalyst surface, with a Co:S ratio of approximately 1:1.16, indicating the successful synthesis of CoS. For both CoS-180@PANI and Co9S8–180@NC, the even distributions of the C and N elements on CoS-180 confirm the successful coating of PANI. The overall presence of oxygen is attributed to surface oxidation. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the synthesized catalysts, clarifying the material property changes due to the synthesis temperature. For CoS-x and CoS-x@PANI, the peaks corresponding to the CoS lattice plane are located at approximately 30.63°, 35.30°, 46.93°, and 54.44°, which are attributed to the (100), (101), (102), and (110) planes, respectively. In the catalysts synthesized at 180 °C and 200 °C, additional peaks corresponding to Co9S8 are observed at approximately 31.20°, 36.18°, and 47.58° for the (222), (400), and (511) planes, respectively, except the catalyst synthesized at 160 °C. Lattice plane peaks corresponding to CoS and Co9S8 are observed in all Co9S8-x@NC catalysts after pyrolysis. The peak intensities increase, and the peak widths decrease. Hence, after pyrolysis, some of the CoS transforms into Co9S8, leading to additional composition changes in the cobalt sulfides and a significant increase in catalyst crystallinity [24,25]. The interlayer spacing corresponding to the peaks observed in the XRD diffraction patterns was calculated using Bragg's law [49]. The interlayer spacing for the Co9S8 (511) plane is 0.191 nm, whereas those for the CoS (100), (101), and (110) planes are 0.292, 0.254, and 0.168 nm, respectively. These calculated values are compared with the interlayer spacing observed in the subsequent TEM images. The Raman spectra of the synthesized catalysts were then observed to identify differences in the cobalt sulfides formed at varying synthesis temperatures. All synthesized catalysts exhibit peaks corresponding to CoS and Co9S8 at approximately 465, 508, and 667 cm−1, which are assigned to the Eg, Fg2, and A1g modes, respectively (Fig. 4 (a)) [50–52]. However, the A1g peak position shows a clear difference, depending on the synthesis temperature and processing stage (Fig. 4(b)). The A1g peak of CoS-160 is at approximately 676 cm−1, which is consistent with the A1g peak position of CoS [53]. For CoS-180 and CoS-200, the A1g peaks are observed at approximately 667 and 660 cm−1, respectively. This downward shift is attributed to the influence of the simultaneously formed Co9S8 [53,54]. After pyrolysis, Co9S8 formation shifts the A1g peak of Co9S8–160@NC to approximately 669 cm−1. Conversely, the A1g peak of Co9S8–200@NC shifts to approximately 669 cm−1 in the positive direction. Here, a lower A1g peak position indicates a longer Co–S bond length [55]. An increase in this bond length leads to a higher electron density around the metal, which is advantageous for the ORR performance [55]. Fig. 4(c) shows the region where the graphitization state and defects of carbon can be examined, revealing four common peaks (G band, C sp3, D band, and C sp2). The C sp3 and C sp2 peaks are at approximately 1220 and 1485 cm−1, respectively, indicating the presence of hydrocarbons within the carbon matrix, amorphous carbon, and distorted structures (such as integrated heteroatoms within the graphene-type lattice) [56,57]. The D and G bands appear at 1360 and 1578 cm−1, respectively. The G band corresponds to the peak of the graphitic carbon, specifically the C–C bond, whereas the D band represents the peak associated with the carbon disorder and defects [56–58]. Among the synthesized catalysts, Co9S8–180@NC has the lowest ID/IG ratio (1.47), indicating a high degree of carbon graphitization [50,57]. The graphitization process can form more pores and expose more active sites [58]. Therefore, among the Co9S8-x@NC samples, Co9S8–180@NC exhibits superior electrocatalytic properties due to its high graphitization and long Co–S bond length. Additionally, the peaks at 1070 and 1146 cm−1, corresponding to PANI, are commonly observed in the Raman spectra of CoS-x@PANI before pyrolysis (Fig. S2). These PANI peaks are observed only in Co9S8–160@NC, possibly due to incomplete graphitization. Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of the synthesized CoS-180, CoS-180@PANI, and Co9S8–180@NC. For CoS-180, a stacked sheet structure is observed, consistent with the SEM images. Additionally, planes corresponding to CoS (100), (110), (101), and Co9S8 (511) are observed in all catalysts, having the same values as the interlayer spacing calculated using Bragg's law. TEM–EDS mapping images are shown. in Fig. 6 . For CoS-180, the element distributions of Co and S are consistent, confirming the formation of CoS. Additionally, the presence of oxygen is presumed to be due to the partial oxidation of the CoS surface. For Co9S8–180@NC, the carbon shell surrounding the Co9S8 core is clear, confirming the success of encapsulation (Fig. 6(d)). Additionally, the elemental composition of the cobalt sulfide core shows a Co-to-S ratio of approximately 1:1, confirming the presence of CoS and Co9S8 phases. Fig. 7 shows the XPS spectra of Co9S8–180@NC. The presence of S, C, O, N, and Co elements is confirmed in Fig. S3(a). In the C 1 s spectra, peaks corresponding to C=C, C–C, C–S, C–O, C–N, and C=O appear at approximately 284.4, 284.7, 284.9, 285.6, 285.8 and 288.1 eV, respectively (Fig. 7(a)) [24,59,60]. Hence, S is doped into PANI, leading to the formation of a carbon shell co-doped with N and S. The surface element ratios of the synthesized catalysts and the deconvolution results for the N 1 s peak are summarized in Tables S1 and S2. The N 1 s spectra are classified into pyridinic N(∼398.2 eV), pyrrolic N/metal N(∼399.2 eV), graphitic N(∼400.5 eV), and oxidized N(∼402.8 eV) based on the bonding position of nitrogen with carbon [33,34,56,61]. During the pyrolysis of CoS-180@PANI, the pyrrolic N/metal N ratio decreases, whereas the ratio of pyridinic N and graphitic N significantly increases (Fig. 7(b) and S3(b)). Pyridinic N, graphitic N, and metal N in NPMCs are important factors for electron transfer and stability and serve as active sites [62–67]. Therefore, ORR electrocatalysts with higher ratios of these types of nitrogen are expected to perform better. However, pyrrolic N and metal (cobalt) N have overlapping peak positions, hindering assignment accuracy [56]. Thus, these signals are attributed to pyrrolic N. Table 2 provides a summary of the nitrogen content and the relative intensity of the N-functional group in Co9S8-x@NC. Co9S8–180@NC exhibits the highest ratio of pyridinic N (31.50 %) and graphitic N (59.43 %). Considering the differences in surface nitrogen content among the catalysts, the ratios of pyridinic N and graphitic N in the surface nitrogen were calculated to compare the actual amounts of N-functional groups. This ratio was defined as at. % eq. The results show that the amounts of pyridinic N and graphitic N in the surface nitrogen of Co9S8–180@NC are 1.56at. % eq. and 2.95at. % eq.; for Co9S8–160@NC, 1.36at. % eq. and 2.84at. % eq.; for Co9S8–200@NC, 1.41at. % eq. and 2.74at. % eq., respectively. Fig. 7(c) and (d) show the Co 2p and S 2p spectra. Peaks corresponding to Co3+ (778.2 and 793.3 eV), Co2+ (780.1 and 796.7 eV), S2− (161.6 and 162.2 eV), and S2 2− (162.8 and 163.5 eV) are observed, confirming the successful formation of cobalt sulfides [58,66]. Additionally, consistent with the C 1 s results, the presence of S doped into PANI is confirmed through the thiophene S (C–S–C; 164.4 and 165.2 eV) peaks [58]. The oxidized S (∼167.8 eV) peak is attributed to surface oxidation. 3.2 Electrochemical characterization of catalysts The ORR performance of the synthesized catalysts was evaluated by conducting LSV analysis (Fig. 8 (a)) in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at a scan rate of 5 mV·s −1 and a potential range of 0.05–1.05 V (vs. RHE). The background current was measured and then corrected using the values obtained in N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at 1600 rpm. The onset potential (the potential at which −0.01 mA·cm−2 was reached) of Co9S8–160@NC and Co9S8–180@NC is 0.8 V, showing modest activity. Despite having the same onset potential, there is a significant difference in the limiting current density between Co9S8–160@NC and Co9S8–180@NC, which results in a difference in the half-wave potential (Table S3). Co9S8–200@NC has onset and half-wave potentials of 0.78 and 0.677 V, respectively (Table S3). The Co9S8–180@NC, which exhibits the best activity among the synthesized catalysts, can be explained by the analyzed Raman, and XPS results. With the lowest ID/IG ratio (1.47) among the synthesized catalysts, it indicates a high degree of graphitization, enhancing the exposure of active sites. Its low A1g peak position suggests a long Co–S bond length, increasing the electron density around the metal, which is beneficial for ORR. According to the deconvolution of the N 1 s spectrum, the presence of abundant pyridinic N and graphitic N within the catalyst facilitates electron transfer. Fig. S4 and Table S3 show the LSV measurement results for all catalysts, which show increasing activity throughout the synthesis process. Co9S8–180@NC exhibits slightly lower ORR activity compared to recently reported cobalt sulfide-based materials (Table S4). However, this may be attributed to differences in synthesis conditions and precursors. Nevertheless, Co9S8–180@NC demonstrates decent catalytic properties due to its high degree of graphitization and nitrogen doping effect, which facilitates electron transfer. The ORR kinetics of the synthesized catalysts were analyzed by calculating Tafel slopes from the LSV curves (Fig. 8(b)) as j k = j L · j j L − j , where jk is the kinetic current density, jL is the limiting current density, and j is the measured current density. Co9S8–180@NC exhibits the lowest Tafel slope of 61.59 mV·dec−1, which is the closest to the value of Pt/C (58.46 mV·dec−1). Co9S8–160@NC and Co9S8–200@NC exhibit higher Tafel slopes of 64.34 and 68.15 mV·dec−1, respectively. A lower Tafel slope indicates better ORR kinetics, and this result aligns with the trends observed in the LSV curves [57,61]. Fig. S5 shows the CV analysis results in the non-faradaic region at scan rates of 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 mV s −1. These results were used to calculate the EDLC (Fig. 8(c)). Co9S8–180@NC exhibits the highest values among the synthesized catalysts, with a capacitance of 0.0027 mF·cm−2. In comparison, Co9S8–160@NC and Co9S8–200@NC have values of 0.0026 and 0.0023 mF cm−2, respectively. This trend is consistent with the LSV curves. Fig. 8(d) shows the EIS results for the synthesized catalysts. Co9S8–180@NC exhibits low resistance, indicating faster charge transfer during the reaction [66,67]. To investigate the ORR pathway of the synthesized catalysts, the electron transfer number (n) and hydrogen peroxide yield were calculated from the ring electrode potential obtained through LSV analysis (Figs. S6, and S7). The number of electron transfers and %H2O2 yield of the synthesized catalysts were calculated using the following equation. n = 4 i D i s k i D i s k + i R i n g N , % H 2 O 2 = 200 i R i n g N i D i s k + i R i n g N . Here, idisk and iRing represent the disk and ring currents, respectively, and N is the collection efficiency, which was set to 0.37 in this study. In the potential range of 0.3–0.7 V, Co9S8–180@NC exhibits an average electron transfer number of 3.80, which is close to that of Pt/C (3.94) and indicates a predominantly four-electron pathway. The average calculated H2O2 yield is 10.04 % (compared with 3.23 % for Pt/C), which is a reasonably good value. The durability of Co9S8–180@NC was analyzed by performing an accelerated stress test (AST) (Fig. 9 (a)) through 10,000 CV cycles at a scan rate of 100 mV s −1 in a potential range of 0.6–1.0 V. The performance degradation based on the half-wave potential was less than 1 %, demonstrating excellent durability. Fig. 9(b) and (c) show the results of the chronoamperometric test (CA) and methanol tolerance tests for Pt/C and Co9S8–180@NC. The CA measurements were conducted at a constant potential of 0.65 V. The results show that Pt/C retains only 71.94 % of its initial performance after 3 h, whereas Co9S8–180@NC maintains 95.49 % of its performance. This indicates that Co9S8–180@NC has superior current stability due to the effective protection of active sites by the encapsulation structure. To clearly confirm the role of the NC layer, a CA measurement was conducted on CoS-180 without NC coating and compared with Co9S8–180@NC (Fig. S8). The CA measurement of CoS-180 showed a current retention of 47.47 % after 3 h, indicating significantly lower durability compared to Co9S8–180@NC. The ORR is also essential for direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). As methanol crossover is a significant flaw in initial performance and durability, the cathode catalyst in a DMFC has to be stable in a methanol tolerance test. This test was conducted at a constant potential of 0.65 V, with methanol injected into the electrolyte at the 300 s mark to achieve a final concentration of 0.1 M. After 3500 s following methanol injection, Pt/C exhibits significant performance degradation, retaining only 59.40 % of its initial performance relative to the injection point. By contrast, Co9S8–180@NC maintains its performance with minimal change, at 98.89 %. The temporary increase in current is due to a transient disturbance in the working electrode caused by methanol injection [68]. After this phenomenon, the current quickly recovers, demonstrating the excellent methanol resistance of Co9S8–180@NC. The excellent durability of Co9S8–180@NC is correlated with the SEM and TEM results. The aggregated PANI encapsulates Co9S8 to form a core-shell structure, protecting the Co9S8 core and thereby suppressing the oxidation and aggregation of active sites, which enhances the catalyst's stability [60,69,70]. 4 Conclusions In this study, CoS was synthesized through a hydrothermal method, coated with PANI, and pyrolyzed to synthesize the Co9S8-x@NC composite catalyst. The effect of the hydrothermal synthesis temperature (specifically 160 °C, 180 °C, and 200 °C) on its ORR performance was examined. The hydrothermal synthesis temperature significantly affected the CoS structure and species. According to the XRD results, CoS-160 exhibited only peaks corresponding to CoS, whereas CoS-180 and CoS-200 exhibited peaks corresponding to both CoS and Co9S8. In other words, Co9S8 formed at temperatures above 180 °C. This was also confirmed by the A1g peak position in the Raman spectra. Its low A1g peak indicated a long Co–S bond, suggesting a higher electron density around Co, which is advantageous for the ORR. The CoS-x structure was observed through SEM. CoS-160 exhibited a flower-like structure; CoS-180, containing Co9S8, exhibited both flower-like and sheet structures; and CoS-200 exhibited a sheet structure. Thus, the synthesis temperature influenced the particle structure. The core–shell structure of Co9S8-x@NC was observed using TEM. Among the synthesized catalysts, Co9S8–180@NC exhibited the highest graphitization degree, along with the highest contents of total N, pyridinic N, and graphitic N, resulting in the highest onset potential (0.8 V) and limiting current density (4.580 mA·cm−2) among the synthesized catalysts. Hence, 180 °C was the most efficient hydrothermal synthesis temperature. Co9S8–180@NC exhibited the lowest Tafel slope (61.59 mV·dec−1). In the AST, a performance degradation of less than 1 % was observed, whereas the CA test demonstrated a current retention rate of 95.49 %, indicating high durability, which was attributed to the core–shell structure. This study contributes to the development of highly active, durable NPMCs that can replace Pt-based catalysts for the ORR. coredata.dc:description: The scarce, expensive Pt is the preferred catalyst for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in metal–air batteries or fuel cells. In this study, a composite catalyst consisting of cobalt sulfide and polyaniline (PANI) was utilized for optimal ORR kinetics. Cobalt sulfide catalysts were prepared at different temperatures, the optimal cobalt sulfide catalyst was coated with PANI, and the coated catalyst was annealed to form a core–shell cobalt sulfide@NC composite catalyst. Structural characterization was performed via X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) were conducted to characterize the catalyst morphology. CoS-160 exhibited a flower-like structure; CoS-180, containing Co9S8, exhibited both flower-like and sheet structures; and CoS-200 exhibited a sheet structure. With an increase in temperature, XRD and Raman spectroscopy verified the formation of Co9S8, serving as ORR active sites, in CoS-180 and CoS-200. HR-TEM indicated that the Co9S8-x@NC catalysts had a core–shell structure. Among them, Co9S8–180@NC had the highest graphitization degree, and total nitrogen, pyridinic N, graphitic N contents, resulting in the highest onset potential, limiting current density and the lowest Tafel slope for ORR in alkaline media among the catalysts. In an accelerated stress test, a performance degradation of less than 1 % was observed, and a chronoamperometry test demonstrated a current retention rate of 95.49 %.
